Chemical Technology Division CSIR-Institute of Himalayan Bioresource Technology Palampur HP 176061 India Polystyrene supported palladium (Pd@PS) nanoparticles (NPs) catalyzed intramolecular aminocarbonylation of 2-iodobenzamides and 2-iodobenzylanilines using bench stable Oxalic acid as in situ CO source for the synthesis of phthalimides and isoindolin-1-one is described. Low catalyst loadings (0.2 mol%, 2000 ppm Pd) with appreciable recyclability up to six cycles, external base free, Oxalic acid as inexpensive and safer in situ C1 source and vast substrate scope are some remarkable features of the present protocol. Furthermore, we scale up the present reaction up to 1.5 gram. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Supported palladium 2-Iodobenzamides 2-Iodobenzylanilines Phthalimides Isoindolinones and Oxalic acid Data Availability The research data relevant to this manuscript is provided as separate file named 'Supporting Information' 1 Introduction N-heterocycles, such as phthalimides and isoindolinon-1-ones, play important structural roles in a wide range of natural, agrochemical and pharmaceutical molecules (Fig. 1 ) [1–13]. It was noticed that about 60% of FDA-approved molecules contain at least one N-heterocycle in their structure [13]. N-substituted phthalimides have a wide range of applications in medicinal chemistry such as anti-tumor [14–16], anti-inflammatory [17–19], anti-convulsant [20–21], anti-angiogenic [22], anti-fungal [23], hypolipidimic [24–26], and antimicrobial activity [27]. Furthermore, N-substituted phthalimides have the potential to be used in the treatment of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) [28–30], leprosy [31,32], oral aphthosis [33] and other related diseases [34–36]. In recent years, they have also been used in the synthesis of crystalline polyimide (PI) covalent organic frameworks (COFs) polymer which has higher thermal stability and surface area than amorphous porous PIs [37,38]. Similarly, N-substituted isoindolin-1-ones are a common structural motif in indoprofen (anti-inflammatory), Lenalidomide (immunomodulatory agent with anti-tumor activity), hericenone B (platelet aggregation inhibitory) and DWP205190 (phosphodiesterase inhibitor) [39–42].Moreover, the utilization of isoindolinones for the synthesis of vital intermediates in organic synthesis is also well known in literature [43–46].Because of the biological and industrial importance of N-heterocycles, particularly phthalimides and isoindolin-1-ones, synthetic chemists have become more interested in developing an effective, environmentally friendly and versatile protocol for their synthesis. In this regard, researchers have established various catalytic and non-catalytic protocols for the synthesis of phthalimides [47–49] and isoindolin-1-ones [50–56] over the past few years. Among the established synthetic protocols, the transition metal catalyzed carbonylative cyclization reaction has emerged as one of the best protocols for producing N-heterocycles [57–63]. It enables the direct and quick synthesis of N-heterocycles using CO surrogates, which also consistent with the atom economy concept [64,65]. In this regard, Ban and co-workers pioneered the Pd-catalyzed carbonylative cyclization reaction of 2-halobenzamides for the synthesis of phthalimides using CO(g) [66]. After one decade, Perry et al. reported Pd(II)-catalyzed double carbonylation reactions of o-dihaloarenes with primary amines and carbon monoxide in the presence of DBU [67]. Later, this double carbonylative approach was further extended by researchers under different palladium catalytic conditions [68–71]. Synthetic chemists have also explored the scope of o-halo benzoic acid/esters with amines and CO or DMF/POCl3 as carbonyl source to synthesize N-substituted phthalimides using a palladium catalyst [72–74]. Bhanage et al. recently reported a phosphine free Pd(II)-catalyzed carbonylative cyclization of o-iodobenzamides to produce the N-substituted phthalimides using phenyl formate as a CO surrogate [75,76]. After that, Sekar et al. reported binaphthyl-supported palladium NPs (Pd-BNP)-catalyzed intramolecular amino-carbonylation of o-iodobenzamides using carbon monoxide and produced N-substituted phthalimides derivatives [77]. Recently, Wu et al. described the Pd(II)-catalyzed carbonylative cyclization strategy with o-iodobenzamides to synthesis N-substituted phthalimides using PPh3/I2/HCOOH combination as CO source [78]. In the literature, transition metal catalyzed direct C-H carbonylation of benzamides yielding N-substituted phthalimides has also been reported [79–81]. The literature survey reveals that, carbonylative cyclization of dihaloaryls, o-halo benzoates, o-halo benzoic acid, N-substituted-2-iodobenzamide derivatives and 2-iodobenzyl bromide analogues have been explored for the synthesis of phthalimides and isoindolin-1-ones using variety of homogeneous as well as heterogeneous palladium complexes. However, the reported methods have some limitations: high catalyst loadings (up to 10 mol%), requires organic or inorganic base, use of air and moisture sensitive ligands, longer reaction time and low functional group tolerance. In addition, requirement of high CO gas pressure implies concerns regarding safety related issues (Scheme 1 ). Over the past decade, our research group has been working on the development of polystyrene supported transition metal nano-catalysts and its application in the area of carbonylation chemistry using Oxalic acid as a CO surrogate [82–87]. Recently, we have also explored our developed transition metal nano-catalyst in carbonylative cyclization strategies for heterocycles synthesis [88–92]. In continuation to our work, herein, we first time reported an external base free and single step approach for the synthesis of phthalimides and isoindolin-1-ones under polystyrene supported palladium nanoparticles (Pd@PS) catalyzed conditions with very low catalyst loadings through carbonylation cyclization strategy. The present protocol has several advantages over reported methods such as low catalyst loading (0.2 mol%), devoid the need of external base, use of Oxalic acid as a safe and bench stable in situ CO source, shorter reaction time, vast substrate scope and different functional group tolerance. In addition, the use of Oxalic acid as in situ CO surrogate eliminates the requirement of highly sophisticated equipment to perform carbonylation reactions. The present methodology is also applicable for gram scale synthesis of phthalimides and isoindolin-1-ones. 2 Results and discussion Initially, we prepared Pd@PS catalyst following our earlier reported reduction-deposition approach [82]. Under this, the solution of 30 mg NaBH4 in 10 mL of water was added to 1 g of Amberlite® IRA 900 Cl− resin (PS) in a 50 mL flask. The resulting heterogeneous mixture was stirred for 4 and 5 h at room temperature. Then, partial borohydride exchanged resin was washed with water to neutralize the pH and later with acetone to remove excess of water from polymer. This exchanged polymer resin (PS-BH4 −) was dried under reduced pressure. The PS-BH4 − (1 g) was added into the warm (at temperature 100°C) solution of palladium acetate (10 mg) in DMF, and the mixture was stirred for few minutes or till the brown colour solution changed to colourless, and simultaneously turned black giving Pd@PS catalyst. The Pd@PS catalyst was filtered through a cotton bed, washed with water and acetone, and dried under reduced pressure. At the beginning of our study, we selected N-phenyl-2-iodobenzamide (1a) as a model substrate to optimize the reaction conditions. We conducted the reaction of 1a with Oxalic acid as C1 source and Pd@PS as a catalyst in toluene at 130 °C for 24 h, the desired product was not obtained, even in traces (Table 1 , entry 1). After exploring the effect of solvent on reaction, the polar aprotic solvents influenced the product yields significantly (Table 1, entries 1-5). As a result, the product yield increased up to 96% with DMF as a solvent (Table 1, entry 6). No alteration in the products yields was observed while reducing the solvent volume 1.5 to 0.5 mL and reaction time 24 to 12 h (Table 1, entries 7-8). Further changing the reaction time to 9 h, catalyst loadings to 0.1 mol%, reaction temperature to 120 °C and proportion of Oxalic acid to 4.0 equiv., all were resulted to decrease in the yield of product 2a (Table 1, entries 9-12). In the absence of Oxalic acid, traces amount of product was detected (Table 1, entry 13). No product formation was observed in the absence of catalyst Pd@PS (Table 1, entry 14). A variety of CO source such as formic acid, N- formylsaccharin, oxalyl chloride and paraformaldehyde were also screened under optimized reaction conditions (Table 1, entries 15-18). The commercially available homogeneous catalytic systems such as PdCl2 and Pd(OAc)2 were also screened under developed conditions and the results were summarized in Table 1 (Entries 19-20). After evaluation of all possible reaction parameters, we have an ideal reaction condition in hand: 1a (0.15 mmol), Pd@PS (0.2 mol% of Pd), Oxalic acid anhydrous (0.90 mmol) and DMF (0.5 mL) at 130 °C for 12 h. Pd@PS showed good catalytic performance in the carbonylative synthesis of N-heterocycles under optimal reaction condition, with a TOF value of 322.58 h−1 (SI, Table 6S). With the optimal reaction conditions in hand, we investigated the structural diversity of N-aryl-2-aminobenzamide to evaluate the reaction scope. Initially, we targeted the scope of N-aryl substituted 2-aminobenzamides and a variety of functionality on aryl moiety were examined, summarized in Table 2 . Electron releasing functionality on the N-phenyl ring irrespective their position gave the corresponding products 2b-2f in 77-94% isolated yields. However, sterically hindered 3,4,5-trimethoxy substituted N-phenyl-2-aminobenzamides gave the moderate yield of corresponding product 2g. The halogen-substituted aryl compounds are important organic feedstocks for the synthesis of valuable complex molecules through cross coupling reactions [93–95]. To our delight, halogen group functionality such as fluoro, chloro, bromo at ortho/meta/para position on the N-phenyl ring were well tolerated under our reaction conditions and gave the anticipated product 2h-n in 64-86% isolated yields. Interestingly, under our reaction conditions, para-hydroxy substitution on N-phenyl ring also gave the corresponding product 2o in 60% isolated yields. Electron withdrawing substituent such as -COCH3, -CO2Me, -CN on the N-phenyl ring had little effect on the reactivity and the desired product 2p-r obtained in moderate to good yields. Interestingly, strong electron withdrawing substituent such as -NO2, -OCF3 on the N-phenyl ring exhibited good reactivity under established catalytic conditions and procured the desired products 2s-t in 49-74% isolated yields. Surprisingly, for the first time, N-(p-benzophenone)-phthalimide (2v) was synthesized by a carbonylative approach with excellent yield (89%). Particularly, this compound has excellent exciplex-forming property that is useful for designing and development of organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs) [96–98]. To further demonstrated the substrate scope of the present protocol, the reaction performances of N-benzyl substituted 2-iodobenzamides were investigated (Table 3 ). Electronically neutral N-benzyl-2-iodobenzamide (3a) under this condition gave the desired product 4a in 65% isolated yield. N-benzyl substituted 2-iodobenzamides (3b-f) having electron donating groups such as -CH3 and -OCH3, regardless of their respective positions on benzyl rings, resulted in good yields (64-77%) of the desired products 4b-f. Halogens such as -F, -Cl, Br substituted N-benzyl-2-iodobenzamides 3g-j reacted efficiently under optimized conditions and gave good to excellent yields (70-88%) of the corresponding products 4g-j. Sterically hindered N-(1-phenylethyl) and N-(1-naphthylmethyl) substituted 2- iodobenzamides (3k and 3l) were also participated in the reaction, gave the desired product 4 k and 4l in 64 and 60% isolated yields respectively. Electron withdrawing group substituted N-benzyl-2-iodobenzamides (3m and 3n) were found to be reactive under similar conditions and delivered the anticipated product 4m and 4n in 82 and 71% isolated yields respectively. Moreover, N-alkyl substituted 2-iodobenzamides were also attempted under standard reaction conditions (Table 4 ). Interestingly, we got N-alkylated product (6a-6f) in 40–85% yields. In case of sterically hindered N-alkyl substitution moderate yields (40 and 50%) of targeted products (6b and 6e) were obtained. Next, we attempted N-cycloalkyl substituted 2-iodobenzamides under standard conditions, the desired products (6g-6j) were obtained in moderate to good yields (52–70%). 2-Iodo-N-phenethylbenzamide was also examined under optimized reaction conditions and gave the desired product 6f in 62% isolated yield. Following our success with carbonylative cyclization of N-substituted 2-iodobenzamides, we turned our attention to N-(2-iodobenzyl)-anilines (Table 5 ). Initially, the optimized conditions for the phthalimide synthesis were used to prepare N-aryl-isoindolin-1-ones. We were pleased to find that a range of N-aryl-isoindolin-1-ones (8a-8j) were produced in good to excellent yields (63–90%) under the same conditions, regardless of the electronic environment of the substitution on the N-aryl ring (8b-8d, methyl; 8e-8f, alkoxy; 8g-8j, halogens). The electron withdrawing substitution (-COCH3) on the N-aryl ring also resulted in a reasonable yield (56%) of the desired product, 8 k. In order to validate the present synthetic protocol for scale up synthesis, we performed the reaction of 1a (1.5 g, 4.6 mmol) as well as 7a (1.2 g, 3.9 mmol) separately under optimized conditions and obtained the corresponding products 2a (N-phenylphthalimide) and 8a (N-phenylisoindolin-1-one) in 78% (0.80 g) and 76% (0.62 g) isolated yields respectively (Scheme 2 ). The gram scale experiments and their results showed the feasibility of present protocol for scalable production of important N-heterocycles. 3 Mercury test and hot filtration test To know the nature of Pd@PS, we carried out a reaction of N-phenyl-2-iodobenzamide (1a) under optimized conditions using 15 equivalent of mercury Hg (0), and then observed the total inhibition of the reaction. This observation showed that the Pd@PS catalyst is heterogeneous in nature. Under ideal reaction conditions, we also conducted a hot filtration test using N-phenyl-2-iodobenzamide (1a). The catalyst Pd@PS was filtered out after four hours, allowing the reaction to continue for another eight hours. However, no progress of the reaction was noticed (Fig. 2 ). This observation proved that the Pd@PS catalyst is heterogeneous in nature, and that no soluble palladium metal was involved for the reaction. 4 Recyclability experiment The stability of Pd@PS catalyst under present catalytic conditions was further investigated and the results shown in Fig. 2. For this investigation, we conducted the reaction of 1a under optimized conditions. After completion of the reaction, the Pd@PS catalyst was removed by filtration, washed with water followed by acetone and then dried. The recovered catalyst was further used for next cycle. To our delight, the Pd@PS catalyst was recycled up to six cycles with slight decrease in the yield of 2a after fourth cycle (Fig. 3 ). On the basis of previous reports, a plausible reaction mechanism was sketched (Fig. 4 ). The catalytic cycle started with the oxidative addition of Pd@PS with (Ar)C-I bond of 1a to give the corresponding palladium complex (I). Next, the acyl palladium complex (II) is obtained after the coordination and insertion of CO, in-situ produced by the thermal decomposition of Oxalic acid. Then, the intramolecular nucleophilic attack of secondary amine on the acyl palladium complex (II) generates III. Here, our polymeric support (PS) (Amberlist IRA 400 Cl− form resin) of the catalyst provided the basic media to the reaction. Finally, reductive elimination from III affords the final product 2a and the catalyst Pd@PS, ready to further participated in the reaction. 5 Conclusions In conclusion, the Pd@PS NPs as catalyst in ppm-level of Pd was found to be highly effective for intramolecular amino-carbonylation of N-aryl-2-aminobenzamides and N-(2-iodobenzyl)-anilines to give variety of N-heterocyclic compounds with considerably good yields. All the reaction has been carried out in a one pot system using Oxalic acid as a CO surrogate that avoid the need of high pressurized system for CO gas, demonstrating high level of efficacy and practicality. Using this method, a series of phthalimides and isoindolin-1-ones with different N-aryl, -benzyl, -alkyl, and -cycloalkyl substitutions were synthesized in excellent to good yields. The present method was also applicable for gram scale synthesis of N-heterocycle. The Pd@PS catalyst separated easily from the reaction mixture and reused up to six-cycles, with a slight decrease in catalytic activity after the fourth cycle. The superior features of present methodology are low catalyst loadings with appreciable recyclability, external base free, Oxalic acid as economic and safer in situ C1 source, vast substrate scope applicability and low solvent volume in comparison to earlier reports. coredata.dc:description: Polystyrene supported palladium (Pd@PS) nanoparticles (NPs) catalyzed intramolecular aminocarbonylation of 2-iodobenzamides and 2-iodobenzylanilines using bench stable Oxalic acid as in situ CO source for the synthesis of phthalimides and isoindolin-1-one is described. Low catalyst loadings (0.2 mol%, 2000 ppm Pd) with appreciable recyclability up to six cycles, external base free, Oxalic acid as inexpensive and safer in situ C1 source and vast substrate scope are some remarkable features of the present protocol. Furthermore, we scale up the present reaction up to 1.5 gram.
coredata.dc:title: Supported-Pd catalyzed carbonylative synthesis of phthalimides and isoindolinones using Oxalic acid as in situ CO surrogate with 2-iodobenzamides and 2-iodobenzylanilines in ppm-level catalyst loading
